noun.description: Wheat or any other cultivated cereal crop used as food.
A single fruit or seed of a cereal.
The smallest unit of weight in the troy and avoirdupois systems, equal to 1/5760 of a pound troy and 1/7000 of a pound avoirdupois (approximately 0.0648 grams).
The longitudinal arrangement or pattern of fibers in wood, paper, etc.
examples: he scored along the grain of the table with the knife

noun.description: A person's character or natural tendency.
Kermes or cochineal, or dye made from either of these.

verb.description: Give a rough surface or texture to.
examples: her fingers were grained with chalk dust

verb.description: Paint (especially furniture or interior surfaces) in imitation of the grain of wood or marble.
examples: the art of graining and marbling
the boots were of best grained leather

phrases: it goes against the grain to tell outright lies
For an estate agent, having to talk a house down instead of up goes against the grain, admits Craig Grantham.
Much as it goes against the grain to praise the legal profession in any way, I was reminded earlier this week of one of the benefits of the profession.
But helping the poor directly would go against the grain of the ruling party's old guard.
When did you last hear a politician genuinely appeal to our higher nature, go against the grain because what they believed in was simply the right thing to do?
origin: Middle English (originally in the sense seed, grain of corn): from Old French grain, from Latin granum.
